This show is what you show other people when trying to invite them into anime. It isn't wild or crazy. It is a simple story. The characters is what makes this story great. The comedy will make you pause the show in order to catch your breath and the ending will leaving you smiling. This is a wholesome show with fun people. Handa is such a relatable person. the art is nothing impressive. but it works perfectly for this kind of anime. If you like this then I suggest you watch "Haven't you heard? I'm sakamoto." If you are looking to laugh or something towatch with the family. This is the show to put on. I like how every episode a side character learns a lesson and believes Handa wanted to teach them. This show not only has character arcs for the side characters. Handa's character slowly evolves as the people around him befriend him.

This show seems to get a lot of shit for.... not being original? The first episode of this show is by far the best. After that it kinda is just a half decent running gag. But its honestly kinda fun to watch. Nothing amazing but enjoyable. The ending was kinda predictable based on the set up but it was still nice, honestly the main problem with this show is that it doesn't vary its jokes enough so it ends up being one of two running gags. Handa thinks he is hated when in fact he is super popular, and thus Handa does something Handa feelsbad about himself  while the other person is like "OMG MR POPULAR." OR The Handa Force do something for Handa to try to help him when in reality its just creepy or misguided. That is basically the show. It's aight and funny but nothing amazing. 7/10

Handa kun is a decent series. It doesn’t compare to Barakamon in terms of quality or comedy though. 
One of the main problems i feel is there’s no variety in comedy. Every character plays up to the same comedic traits/gags they have. I kinda got bored of the same old misunderstandings, everyone dickriding how great Handa is and Handa being such a shy, negative, loner teen that interprets everything as some hate towards him. It’s why when Kawafuji points out that he’s actually popular and liked in the last 10 mins of the last episode it felt forced. Like it took Handa 11 1/2 episodesto realise that, really?? 


Most of the characters were fleshed out well and had some development (even if it was because of some influence that Handa inadvertly did). However, Handa got no development in comparison, which is ironic considering one of the criticisms I had with Barakamon is only Handa received character development. I kinda wanted to see him develop into the more outgoing and fun version he is as an adult because his teen self almost feels like a completely different character.


The opening song is alright, I like how creative and fun the visuals are. The osts are great, i love “Handa’s theme” that plays whenever he’s on screen. It’s like a aloof, lighthearted soundtrack. The ending song is kinda weak and forgettable.  


Overall, I’ll give Handa-kun a 4/10 because it allowed me to learn more about my Handa-kun. I hope to see the Handa force in Barakamon or i’m going be really disappointed ;(

Handa-kun, in my opinion, is a relaxing but comical anime. As the summery states, it really is about a guy who thinks everyone is out to get him when instead everyone loves him. To see the dynamic between the two and how Handa freaks out when he's the center of attention makes it absolutely hilarious to watch and honestly what kept me hooked onto all 12 episodes. Not to mention all the "life lessons" everyone learns after Handa does something. I liked how the anime was pretty simple in of its self. Yeah it was a tad bit on the bland side, but nothing toobad. I highly recommend this anime if you're having a long day at work/school or when you've finished studying. Like i stated it's a chill anime, and just quirky in it's own way.

This show have a lot of undeserved bad reviews. I think the reason is people was expecting this to be the same of Barakamon and it was not. When you like something in the way it is, you don't want it to change. And Handa-kun have a diferent spirit than it's sequel, which is not so oriented to humor but to a heartwarming slice of life kind of thing. If you haven't watched Barakamon yet or you have not problem with this to be diferent, you will able to enjoy an actually good comedy with a unique personality. I rate by enjoyment and I gaveit a solid eight.

A prologue to Barakamon, Handa-kun gives fans of the first series a peek into Handa Sei's life as a high school student before he became the arrogant yet insecure calligrapher we came to know and love.
First off, what's wrong with Handa-kun?  Lots of things, when you compare it to Barakamon.  While the previous series allowed us to experience Handa's journey as he discovered different aspects of himself and his work in a very comedic and inspiring way, Handa-kun imply reminds us in each and every episode that Handa is incredibly insecure, overly anxious, and surrounded by idiotic Handa-worshipers who read into everything waytoo much and, in their pursuit of making Handa happy, actually make him pretty miserable.



Putting that aside, Handa-kun will make you laugh, or at least chuckle.  It was easier for me to enjoy this series after I told myself this isn't meant to be like Barakamon, it's just a ridiculous high school slice of life comedy that's supposed to show the ridiculous antics of Handa's class mates and how their over enthusiasm affects Handa.  


There is no development until the last episode, and I can't even call it development, it was more like someone finally popped the bubble and said "Hey, no one actually hates you!"  


The art isn't as good as Barakamon, it actually looked like it took a step down. 


 The characters were stupid, I'm not kidding here, they were dumb.  The only smart one was Kawafuji, but he was barely in the series....


I didn't commit to the series, it took me months to watch all 12 episodes, unlike Barakamon, which I committed to all night and part of a day.  It doesn't really add to Barakamon's story, it barely even touches on Handa and Kawafuji's friendship, and if you watched Barakamon and never even considered to watcha Handa-kun, you wouldn't be missing a thing.  


In the end, it wasn't all that bad.  I laughed, and I even related to Handa (not so much on the popularity scale, but the walls and teen anxiety).  Watch it if you want, but you don't have to.....

Main feature was the humor. Watching how two absolutely different views unwittingly continued to develop each other was hilarious. Although it wasn't the most sophisticated kind of humour, it combined with this story made me laugh every episode. So yeah it is pritty good comedy, it will make you laugh, but I feel like It could be something more ...
Anyway, what kind of buged were the (unintentional I presume) gay vibes ... I just could not fully enjoy segments with them. .  . and rather slow and confusing start.
I gave i only 7/10 because I feel like it could do (somehow) more than this.But still, good anime.

When I heard about the spin-off of Barakamon about Handa-sensei's high school career, I thought it sounded really lame and put off watching it for quite a while.
When I finally got around to watching it, it seemed... really lame! I thought the first episode (or at least, the first half of it) was weird and not funny at all. I had low expectations for the show and it seemed like those expectations were going to be accurate.
After watching a few episodes, though, I started to enjoy the humor of it. Handa's character was really funny and cute to me. The characters around him (the HandaForce) were definitely a stretch and a little cringe-y, but I got used to them and they were okay. I liked Yukio a lot.\n\n
I ended up laughing a lot from the show, in the end. I think if you end up basing your judgement of it by Barakamon, you won't enjoy it, but if you have an open mind, you might. In the end, it was kind of lame, in the way that a bad pun is lame. But I enjoyed it for that.

I've only watched about 4 episodes of Barakamon, the anime that Handa-kun is based off. I remember thinking it was pretty good but for some reason or another, stopped watching it. But I did watch this show which is completely different from Barakamon. Whereas Barakamon is a more serious show about Handa's calligraphy, this is more to do with Handa in highschool and although he still does calligraphy as part of his character, its not very important in the this show.
Handa-kun is a spin-off and a gag anime without any real plot. I don't think you need to watch barakamon or know anything about theshow to gain some enjoyment from this show. This could be a good if you've never watched Barakamon but it may also be dissapointing for fans of Barakamon that expected something more substantial. 


The whole show centers around the running-gag that Handa is extremely popular in the school but that Handa himself thinks that he is hated by everyone. This is done ad nasuem throughout the entire show and it's predictable and gets boring pretty much after maybe episode 7. It has its peak moments but for the most part the show is fine with treading safely and not taking too many risks in terms of story, character development or in the comedy. 


It's an okay show if you want something to just pass the time or are running low on anime to watch and don't want to watch something that you know you want to set aside time to really enjoy.
